questions.text: What is the pinna made up of?
questions.solution: The pinna and the external auditory canal are made up of yellow elastic cartilage. It is also called the auricular cartilage.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman undergoes a rhinoplasty procedure to correct a deformity of her nose. Auricular cartilage is harvested from her right pinna. Which of the following sites cannot be used to harvest the cartilage?
questions.solution:
Incisura terminalis cannot be used to harvest cartilage as it is devoid of cartilage.

It is the part of the pinna between the tragus and the crus of helix. Being devoid of cartilage, the incision for endaural approach for ear surgery can be made here.

The lobule is also devoid of cartilage. Hence, it is the safest site for piercing.

The parts of the pinna are:

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the skin over the pinna?
questions.solution:
The skin over the pinna is loosely adherent on the medial or cranial side. Hence, it is pinchable.

The skin is firmly adherent to the perichondrium on the lateral side and is non-pinchable.

questions.text: What is the length of external auditory canal?
questions.solution:
The length of the external auditory canal is about 24 mm.

It extends from the bottom of the concha to the tympanic membrane. It has two parts:

  • Outer cartilaginous part - 8mm
  • Inner bony part- 16mm

Related Pearl: External Auditory Canal

Part Cartilaginous Bony
Proportions Lateral 1/3 Medial 2/3
Length 8mm 16mm
Made of Auricular yellow elastic cartilage Bony margins of the temporal bone (squamous part superiorly and mastoid part posteriorly)
Direction Upward, backward, medially Downward, forward, medially
Skin is Thick Thin, continuous over tympanic membrane
Skin contains Hair, ceruminous & pilosebaceous glands. Produce wax ---
Deficiencies Fissures of Santorini Foramen of Huschke

questions.text: You are an intern asked to do an otoscopic examination of a young adult. In which direction will you pull the pinna to visualize the tympanic membrane?
questions.solution:
The pinna has to be pulled upwards, backwards and laterally to visualise the tympanic membrane. This is done to bring the bony and cartilaginous parts of the external auditory canal in alignment.

The inner bony part is directed downwards, forwards, and medially.

The outer cartilaginous part is directed upwards, backwards, and medially.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the external auditory canal?

choices.text: Outer 1/3rd is cartilaginous and inner 2/3rd is bony
Outer 2/3rd is cartilaginous and inner 1/3rd is bony
Outer 1/3rd is bony and inner 2/3rd is cartilaginous
Outer 2/3rd is bony and inner 1/3rd is cartilaginous

questions.solution:
The outer 1/3rd is cartilaginous (8mm) and the inner 2/3rd is bony (16mm) in the external auditory canal.

Related Pearl: External Auditory Canal

Part Cartilaginous Bony
Proportions Lateral 1/3 Medial 2/3
Length 8mm 16mm
Made of Auricular yellow elastic cartilage Bony margins of the temporal bone (squamous part superiorly and mastoid part posteriorly)
Direction Upward, backward, medially Downward, forward, medially
Skin is Thick Thin, continuous over tympanic membrane
Skin contains Hair, ceruminous & pilosebaceous glands. Produce wax ---
Deficiencies Fissures of Santorini Foramen of Huschke

questions.text: A patient with otitis externa develops parotitis. You suspect that the infection has spread through the fissures of Santorini. Which of the following best describes this fissure?

choices.text: Connection between middle ear and pharynx
Connection between Inner ear and middle ear

questions.solution:
Fissures of Santorini are the two deficiencies in the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal. They provide a pathway for the spread of parotid or superficial mastoid infections to the canal or vice versa.

The bony canal also has a deficiency called the foramen of Huschke which acts as a pathway for the spread of infections and tumours to the deep lobe of the parotid.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the external auditory canal?

choices.text: Outer 2/3rd is cartilaginous and inner 1/3rd is bony part
Furuncles are seen in the cartilaginous part
Fissures of Santorini are present in bony part and permits parotid and superficial mastoid infections to spread to canal
Isthmus is present at junction of cartilaginous and fibrous part

questions.solution:
Furuncles (staphylococcal infection of the hair follicles) are seen only in the outer one-third of the canal since hair is confined to the outer canal.

Skin is also very tightly adherent to the cartilage and hence furuncles are extremely painful.

Related Pearl: External Auditory Canal

Part Cartilaginous Bony
Proportions Lateral 1/3 Medial 2/3
Length 8mm 16mm
Made of Auricular yellow elastic cartilage Bony margins of the temporal bone (squamous part superiorly and mastoid part posteriorly)
Direction Upward, backward, medially Downward, forward, medially
Skin is Thick Thin, continuous over tympanic membrane
Skin contains Hair, ceruminous & pilosebaceous glands. Produce wax ---
Deficiencies Fissures of Santorini Foramen of Huschke

questions.text: What are ceruminous glands?
questions.solution:
Ceruminous glands are modified apocrine sweat glands. They open into hair follicles & participate in wax production.

Apocrine glands release their products by decapitation. It is a process by which membrane-bound cytoplasm from the apical surface of the cells buds off into the lumen of the duct and is secreted.

Some apocrine glands have specific names. Those on the eyelids are referred to as Moll’s glands, and those on the external auditory meatus are termed ceruminous glands.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding isthmus?

choices.text: It is just lateral to the petrotympanic suture.
It is at the bony cartilaginous junction of EAC.
It is the narrowest part of ear canal.

questions.solution:
The isthmus is the narrowest part of the external auditory canal (EAC).

EAC measures about 24 mm long, cartilaginous part forms the outer one-third (8 mm) and bony part forms two-third (16 mm) of the canal. Isthmus is situated 6 mm lateral to the tympanic membrane in the bony part of the EAC. Foreign bodies that go beyond the isthmus are difficult to remove and are called impacted.

questions.text: You observe a normal-looking tympanic membrane on otoscopy. What is its colour?
questions.solution: The normal tympanic membrane is pearly grey in color. It is thin and semitranslucent.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the tympanic membrane?

choices.text: It is derived from all 3 germ layers
It seperates external from middle ear

questions.solution:
Peripheral parts are more mobile than the central part where the handle of the malleus is attached

The tympanic membrane develops from all three germinal layers. It has 3 layers –

  • Outer epithelial layer from ectoderm
  • Middle fibrous layer from mesoderm
  • Inner mucosal layer endoderm.

Related Pearl: Tympanic membrane

Parts of the tympanic membrane

Pars Tensa
Pars Flaccida
Taut
Loose
Middle fibrous layer is well organized
Middle fibrous layer is not well organized
Contains annulus tympanicus
 Also called Shrapnell’s membrane
Transmits sound
Does not transmit sound

Layers of the tympanic membrane

  Outer Middle Inner
Layer Epithelium Fibrous Mucosa
Continuous with Skin of EAC - Middle ear mucosa
Derived from Ectoderm Mesoderm Endoderm
Made of - Circular, radial & parabolic fibers -

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the tympanic membrane?
questions.solution:
The tympanic membrane has a thickness of 0.1mm.

The dimensions of the tympanic membrane are

  • Length: 9-10mm
  • Width: 8-9mm
  • Area: 90 mm2
  • Subtends an angle of 55° with horizontal 

The medial (inner) surface is convex and the lateral surface is concave. The most depressed part of its concavity is called the umbo, to which the tip of the malleus is attached.

Image: Right tympanic membrane

questions.text: What is the other name for Shrapnell’s membrane?
questions.solution:
Pars flaccida is also known as Shrapnell’s membrane.

Pars flaccida is situated above the lateral process of malleus between the notch of Rivinus and the anterior and posterior mallear folds.

Related Pearl: Tympanic membrane

questions.text: During an otoscopic examination of a patient, where will the cone of light be seen on the tympanic membrane?
questions.solution: A bright cone of light can be seen radiating from the tip of malleus (umbo) to the periphery in the anteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves supply a major part of pinna?
questions.solution:
Greater auricular nerve (C2,C3) supplies most of the medial surface and posterior portion of lateral surface of the external ear.

Nerve Derivation Region supplied

Greater/Great auricular nerve

Cervical plexus C2,C3 

Medial surface and posterior part of the lateral surface
Lesser occipital nerve

Cervical plexus C2

 Superior portion of medial surface
Auricular branch Vagus (X) Concha and antihelix
Some supply medial surface (eminetia concha)
Auriculotemporal nerve

Mandibular (V3)

 Tragus, crus of helix and adjacent helix
Facial (VII)   Small region in the root of concha and retroauricular groove

questions.text: A patient develops tingling and numbness along the upper part of the medial surface of the pinna. Which nerve is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
The upper part of the medial surface of the pinna is supplied by the lesser occipital nerve.

Nerve Derivation Region supplied

questions.text: A patient coughs when removing excess cerumen from the ear. This is due to the stimulation of which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
Reflex cough is due to stimulation of the auricular branch of vagus. It can occur when cleaning or during an examination of the ear.

Nerve Derivation Region supplied

Greater/Great auricular nerve

Cervical plexus C2,C3 

Medial surface and posterior part of the lateral surface
Lesser occipital nerve

Cervical plexus C2

 Superior portion of medial surface
Auricular branch Vagus (X) Concha and antihelix
Some supply medial surface (eminetia concha)
Auriculotemporal nerve

Mandibular (V3)

 Tragus, crus of helix and adjacent helix
Facial (VII)   Small region in the root of concha and retroauricular groove

questions.text: What is Arnold's nerve?
questions.solution:
Auricular branch of vagus (CN X) is also called Arnold’s nerve or Alderman's nerve.

Tympanic branch of CN IX is also called Jacobson’s nerve. 

Sensory root of the facial nerve is also called the nerve of Wrisberg and carries secretomotor fibres to the lacrimal gland and salivary glands, and brings fibres of taste and general sensation.

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerves do not supply the tympanic membrane?
questions.solution:
The spinal accessory nerve (CN XI) does not supply the tympanic membrane. It is supplied by:

  • Lateral surface -
    • Anterior half by auriculotemporal nerve (CN V3)
    • Posterior half by auricular branch of vagus nerve (CN X).
  • Medial surface -
    • Tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (Jacobson's nerve) CN IX.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with bleeding from his ear following a road traffic accident. Which of the following could be its reason?
questions.solution:
A temporal bone fracture can cause bleeding from the ear as it is related to the roof of the middle ear and the external auditory canal.

The relations of the external auditory canal are:

  • Superior - Middle cranial fossa
  • Inferior - Parotid gland
  • Anterior - Temporomandibular joint
  • Posterior - Mastoid air cells and facial nerve.

questions.text: Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to?
questions.solution:
Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (Arnold's nerve).

Arnold's nerve supplies the concha and corresponding eminence on the medial surface. It also supplies the posterior wall and floor of the external auditory canal. Scratching or mechanical stimulation of the ear leads to activation of Arnold's nerve, which evokes reflex cough (ear-cough reflex/otorespiratory reflex).  

Causes of referred otalgia Nerve responsible Site
Temporomandibular joint and dental conditions, parotid infections/tumor, and anterior 2/3rd of tongue Auriculotemporal nerve Tragal area, crus of the helix, and anterior wall and roof of the external auditory canal. 
Acute tonsillitis, peritonsillar abscess, carcinoma base of the tongue or tonsils (oropharynx) The glossopharyngeal nerve (Jacobson's) Medial surface of the tympanic membrane, and middle ear
Carcinoma of the larynx (cough), hypopharynx, epiglottis, vallecula, esophagus, and thyroid Auricular branch of the vagus nerve (Arnold's/Alderman's nerve) Concha, posterior wall, and floor of the external auditory canal
Cervical spondylitis Great auricular nerve (C2,3) Lateral and medial surfaces of the pinna
Acoustic neuroma Facial nerve (nervus intermedius/nerve of Wrisberg)

Concha, retro auricular groove, and posterosuperior part of the external auditory meatus. Numbness in the posterosuperior meatal wall known as Hitzelberger's sign, is seen in acoustic neuroma.
